message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest rotator cuff tendinitis. Musculoskeletal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the injury. Surgical fixation is only needed in severe cases and biopsy of the humerus is not indicated given the patient’s history and lack of other clinical findings. Reassurance alone is not sufficient management for the patient’s severe pain and limited mobility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with severe pain in his left shoulder, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the left humerus, limited external rotation, and inability to slowly adduct his arm after it is passively abducted to 90 degrees. X-ray shows sclerosis of the acromion and humeral head, suggesting rotator cuff tear. Musculoskeletal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management as it can confirm the diagnosis of rotator cuff tear before considering surgical fixation. Reassurance is not appropriate here as the patient presents with severe pain and limited range of motion. Biopsy of the humerus is not necessary without more indications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest rotator cuff tear or tendinopathy, and ultrasound is a good way to confirm this diagnosis. Surgical fixation may be necessary if conservative management fails, but it is not the next appropriate step. Biopsy of the humerus is not indicated without further suspicion of malignancy. Reassurance alone is not appropriate given the severity of the patient’s pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy or tear, and musculoskeletal ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the damage before considering treatment options. Surgical fixation may be considered for severe cases, but it is not the next step in management. Biopsy is not necessary for this presentation. Reassurance alone is not appropriate since the patient is experiencing severe pain and limited mobility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with severe pain in the left shoulder, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the left humerus, and limited external rotation. The x-ray shows sclerosis of the acromion and humeral head, which suggests rotator cuff tendinopathy or tear. Musculoskeletal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management as it can help confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate treatment. Surgical fixation or biopsy may be necessary in some cases, but should not be the first step without confirming the diagnosis. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient is experiencing severe pain and limited mobility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest rotator cuff disease. X-ray showed sclerosis of acromion and humeral head, which is consistent with chronic rotator cuff tear or impingement syndrome. Musculoskeletal ultrasound is a useful tool to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the severity of the tear. Surgical fixation is usually reserved for severe or refractory cases. Biopsy of the humerus is not indicated. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient is experiencing severe pain and limited mobility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest rotator cuff tear, which is common in older adults and those with osteoarthritis. Musculoskeletal ultrasound is an appropriate next step as it can confirm or rule out the diagnosis without the need for more invasive procedures. Surgical fixation or biopsy may be necessary for confirmation or treatment depending on the severity of the tear, but these options are not appropriate as the initial step. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient is experiencing severe pain and limited mobility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests rotator cuff disease, and musculoskeletal ultrasound is helpful in confirming this diagnosis. Surgical fixation may be indicated if conservative measures fail, but it is not the next step in management. Biopsy of the humerus is unlikely to provide useful information, and reassurance alone is not sufficient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy, which is a common cause of shoulder pain, especially in older adults. Musculoskeletal ultrasound is a useful tool to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment, such as corticosteroid injections or physical therapy. Surgical fixation is not indicated at this point, and biopsy of the humerus is not necessary. Reassurance alone is not sufficient as the patient is experiencing severe pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy or tear. Musculoskeletal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm and visualize the tendinopathy or tear before any surgical intervention. Surgical fixation or biopsy may be needed depending on the findings on ultrasound. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient is experiencing severe pain and limited mobility.
